title: Aggregation of Shap Values for time-series (3D) data
body:
I've been working on a time series problem of sorts and have been trying to use SHAP to interpret the results. Being a time series the data comes as a 3D array (#Samples, #Sequences, #Features)

I've come up with the below aggregation method to effectively create  mean shap values in the shape of (#Samples, #Features). 

The approach seems to be generally working so far in that the explanations are making sense, one thing I have noticed is that the force plot values for probabilities become weaker. I.e. it's very rare to see a prediction go close to 1 or 0. The force plots are still correct they just to tend to hover a bit above or below the base value. 

Does this sort of approach make sense to you and do you think there's a more intuitive way I could be handling the SHAP values?

Thanks!




```python
    def aggregate_shap_values(self):
        shap_array = np.array(self.shap_values[0]) # array of shap values computed for time series

        mean_shaps = []

        for i in range(shap_array.shape[0]):
            max_seq_length = shap_array.shape[1]
            for k in range(shap_array.shape[1]):
                if i != 0 and k != 0:  # buggy index I skip over
                    # boolean check for zeroed out padded rows
                    all_zero = not np.all(self.data[i, k, ] == 0)
                    if all_zero:  # if row k is all zero
                        max_seq_length = k
            mean_shaps.append(shap_array[i, :max_seq_length, :].mean(axis=0).tolist()) 
        self.shap_values = np.array(mean_shaps)
```
